title: 111_s3292
content: The Act may be cited as the "Weekends Without Hunger Act" and aims to address hunger on weekends and holidays. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for addressing hunger on weekends and holidays, defining terms like 'at-risk school child' and 'eligible institution'. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include provisions for a pilot program providing nutritious food to at-risk school children on weekends and holidays through eligible institutions like schools, food banks, and homeless shelters. Eligibility criteria are established for receiving commodities for this purpose. To be eligible for receiving commodities under this program, eligible institutions must submit an application to the Secretary with a plan for distributing nutritious foods to at-risk school children, ensuring that children are not publicly separated or identified. To be eligible for receiving commodities under this program, eligible institutions must submit an application to the Secretary with a plan for distributing nutritious foods to at-risk school children, ensuring that children are not publicly separated or identified. The application should include lists of food types, provisions for food quality and safety, number of at-risk children to be served, per-child cost, and any other necessary information determined by the Secretary. Priority is given to institutions with ongoing programs and experience serving. To be eligible for receiving commodities under this program, institutions must have ongoing programs serving at-risk school children, experience in food delivery and safety, high quality control standards, provide nutritious food, show cost efficiencies, and ability to continue projects for the full term. The Secretary will issue guidelines for the program. The Secretary will issue guidelines for projects to receive commodities under this program, considering geographical variations and different types of projects serving nutritious foods to at-risk school children on weekends and school holidays. The Secretary will evaluate a pilot program providing nutritious foods to at-risk school children on weekends and school holidays, with a final report due to Congress by December 31, 2015. Funding of not less than $10,000,000 annually will be used to purchase commodities for the program. The unspent funds for approved pilot projects cannot be fully utilized until September 30, 2015. The Secretary can use up to 3 percent of the funds for project review expenses.
